abstract.p: Human Rights Watch executive director Kenneth Roth letter, responding to Oct 12 front-page article on whether Pres Slobodan Milosevic should face trial before international war crimes tribunal in the Hague or before court in Yugoslavia, suggests international tribunal is appropriate forumg

block.p: An Oct. 12 front-page article addresses the issue of whether Slobodan Milosevic should face trial before the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague or before a court in Yugoslavia. Richard H. Haas, a former National Security Council official, said: ''I would not make coughing up Milosevic the No. 1 priority. After all, he was largely killing his own people, and he can be tried in his own country.''

An Oct. 12 front-page article addresses the issue of whether Slobodan Milosevic should face trial before the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague or before a court in Yugoslavia. Richard H. Haas, a former National Security Council official, said: ''I would not make coughing up Milosevic the No. 1 priority. After all, he was largely killing his own people, and he can be tried in his own country.''

In fact, the vast majority of Mr. Milosevic's victims were not ''his own people.'' They were residents of Bosnia and Croatia. Even his victims in Kosovo, a part of Yugoslavia, were mostly ethnic Albanians rather than the ethnic Serbs who dominate the Yugoslav federation. Given the nature of his crimes and the feeble state of the Yugoslavian judiciary, an international tribunal is the appropriate forum.
KENNETH ROTH Exec. Dir., Human Rights Watch New York, Oct. 13, 2000
